headline: Cadence (CDNS) Stock Trades Up, Here Is Why
summary: Shares of semiconductor design software provider Cadence Design Systems (NASDAQ:CDNS) jumped 5% in the afternoon session after the U.S. government lifted export restrictions on certain chip design software to China. The move signaled a de-escalation in a trade dispute that had previously required U.S. firms to obtain licenses for selling specific electronic design automation (EDA) tools in China. Cadence, a major player in the EDA software market, confirmed it was restoring access for its Chines

headline: Datadog, Synopsys & Cadence, TripAdvisor: Trending Tickers
summary: Datadog (DDOG) stock soars after S&P Global (SPGI) announced the company will replace Juniper Networks (JNPR), which was just acquired by HPE (HPE), in the S&P 500 (^GSPC) on Wednesday, July 9. Shares of Synopsys (SNPS) and Cadence Design (CDNS) climb after the US lifted restrictions on chip design software sales in China. TripAdvisor (TRIP) stock surges after The Wall Street Journal reported that activist investor Starboard has taken a more than 9% stake in the company. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Jobs Report: Fed Rate Cut Odds Sink As Unemployment Falls; S&P 500 Rises (Live Coverage)
summary: The June jobs report showed that hiring stayed solid in June, while the unemployment rate unexpectedly fell.  One big surprise: Half the hiring came from government jobs, which may just reflect seasonal adjustment issues.  The S&P 500 rose moderately after the jobs report, as did the 10-year Treasury yield.

headline: Cadence and Siemens climb, TSM rallies: Trending Tickers
summary: Cadence Design Systems (CDNS) and Synopsys (SNPS) shares rose after the US Commerce Department eased export restrictions, allowing them to resume business with clients in China. Siemens (SIE.DE) stock climbed after the company confirmed it restored full access to software and resumed sales to Chinese customers. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSM) gained after analysts raised their price target and a Reuters report that Intel (INTC) is exploring scaling back efforts to compete in advanced chip manufacturing. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief: Market Sunrise here.

headline: Synopsys, Cadence shares soar as U.S. rescinds chip software curbs on China
summary: Investing.com -- The U.S. has lifted export restrictions on semiconductor design software to China, according to announcements Thursday from three of the industry’s top players—Siemens AG (ETR:SIEGn), Synopsys (NASDAQ:SNPS), and Cadence Design Systems (NASDAQ:CDNS).

headline: Chip design software firms climb as US lifts curbs on China exports
summary: (Reuters) -Shares of Synopsys and Cadence Design Systems jumped on Thursday after the U.S. lifted export curbs on chip design software to China, easing uncertainty around access to the crucial market.  The easing trade tensions may also clear the path for long-awaited Chinese approval of Synopsys's $35 billion buyout of engineering software firm Ansys, the analysts added.  Synopsys, which had pulled its forecast in May due to the curbs, rose 5.5%.

raw.headline: Chip design software firms climb as US lifts curbs on China exports
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Shares of Synopsys and Cadence Design Systems jumped on Thursday after the U.S. lifted export curbs on chip design software to China, easing uncertainty around access to the crucial market.  The easing trade tensions may also clear the path for long-awaited Chinese approval of Synopsys's $35 billion buyout of engineering software firm Ansys, the analysts added.  Synopsys, which had pulled its forecast in May due to the curbs, rose 5.5%.

headline: Siemens says US has lifted chip software curbs on China, Bloomberg News reports
summary: Siemens has restored complete access to its software and technology for customers in China, Bloomberg reported.  The German company and the U.S. Department of Commerce did not immediately respond to Reuters' requests for comment.  In May, the U.S. ordered several companies including Siemens' EDA unit, Cadence and Synopsys to obtain licenses before exporting goods, such as design software and chemicals for semiconductors, to China.

In May, the U.S. ordered several companies including Siemens' EDA unit, Cadence and Synopsys to obtain licenses before exporting goods, such as design software and chemicals for semiconductors, to China.
